title: 110_hr3469
content:
The Act titled "America's Border Security Act of 2007" may be cited as such. It includes provisions related to technological assets. The Act "America's Border Security Act of 2007" mandates increased use of Department of Defense equipment for surveillance at US borders to prevent illegal immigration. The "America's Border Security Act of 2007" requires a report from the Secretaries of Homeland Security and Defense on the current and planned use of Department of Defense equipment for border surveillance, assessing risks and foreign policy implications. During a 1-year period, the Secretary of Homeland Security will conduct a pilot program using unmanned aerial vehicles for border surveillance along the international border between Canada and the United States. The program aims to test the effectiveness of this technology in enhancing border security. The Secretary of Homeland Security will conduct a pilot program using unmanned aerial vehicles for border surveillance along the international border between Canada and the United States. This program aims to test the technology's effectiveness in enhancing border security without altering the prohibition on using the Army or Air Force as a posse comitatus. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 to support this initiative. SEC. 3. INFRASTRUCTURE.

The Secretary of Homeland Security is tasked with constructing roads, acquiring vehicle barriers, and facilities to control the international borders of the United States. Quarterly progress reports to Congress are required, and appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 to support these efforts. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to construct additional ports of entry along the international land borders of the United States and make necessary improvements to existing ports of entry. Additionally, secure communication measures are to be implemented. The Secretary of Homeland Security is tasked with developing a plan to enhance satellite communications for clear and secure 2-way communication among Border Patrol agents, their stations, residents in remote areas along international borders, and other relevant border security agencies. The plan aims to improve satellite communications for Border Patrol agents and relevant border security agencies, including Department and State, local, and tribal law enforcement agencies. SEC. 6. UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLES. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to acquire and maintain at least 5 unmanned aerial vehicles and related equipment for patrolling the US international borders. This includes additional sensors, critical spares, satellite command and control, and other necessary operational support equipment. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2008 and 2009 to fund these activities. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2008 and 2009 to acquire and maintain unmanned aerial vehicles and related equipment for border patrolling. Amounts appropriated are authorized to remain available until expended. SEC. 7. SURVEILLANCE TECHNOLOGIES PROGRAMS. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to develop and implement an aerial surveillance program to enhance border security with Canada and Mexico, utilizing technologies like unmanned aerial vehicles. The Secretary of Homeland Security is mandated to establish an aerial surveillance program for monitoring the US-Mexico border, considering various technologies and assessing their effectiveness in addressing border threats. The Secretary of Homeland Security must consult with the Secretary of Defense and the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration for deploying technologies along the US international border and ensuring safety and airspace coordination for the aerial surveillance program. The aerial surveillance program developed under this subsection will use various technologies in different terrains, including near international borders, to assess the effectiveness and cost of these technologies for border security and critical infrastructure protection. The Secretary of Homeland Security may continue using aerial surveillance technologies to assess their effectiveness for border security. A report to Congress is required within 180 days. The Secretary of Homeland Security must report to Congress within 180 days after implementing the program, including a description and recommendations for enhancement. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the program. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to establish a program, known as the Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program, to procure various technologies for border control. This program aims to achieve operational control of the international borders of the United States by implementing a "virtual fence" using unmanned aerial vehicles, cameras, sensors, and other necessary equipment. The Secretary ensures that technologies in the Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program work together seamlessly, with motion sensor alerts activating cameras automatically. Cameras in the program do not require manual operation. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program includes cameras that are not manually operated, have flexible views, and can be viewed at multiple centers. A standard process is used for collecting intrusion data, and future technology upgrades can be integrated with existing systems. Performance measures are developed and applied. Performance measures are developed and applied to evaluate the Program's effectiveness in monitoring and detecting illegal intrusions along the US international borders. Plans are in place to streamline site selection and installation processes for surveillance technology infrastructure. Standards are being developed to expand the shared use of existing private resources. The Secretary of Homeland Security will expand the use of private and governmental structures for remote surveillance technology and develop standards for nonpermanent surveillance platforms to enhance mobility and detect border intrusions. A report to Congress is required within one year of implementing the Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program. The Secretary of Homeland Security will submit a report to Congress on the Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program, including a description of the program and any recommendations for improvement. Standards will be developed to evaluate contractors providing goods or services for the program. The Inspector General of the Department will review new contracts related to the Automated Surveillance Program worth over $5,000,000 to ensure compliance with cost requirements, performance objectives, milestones, and schedules. Reports on the findings of each review will be submitted. The Inspector General will review new contracts for the Automated Surveillance Program over $5,000,000 to ensure compliance. Findings will be reported to the Secretary of Homeland Security within 30 days for submission to relevant committees. The Inspector General will review new contracts for the Automated Surveillance Program over $5,000,000 and report findings to the Secretary of Homeland Security for necessary actions. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose. SEC. 8. HIRING AND TRAINING OF BORDER AND TRANSPORTATION SECURITY PERSONNEL. During fiscal year 2008, the Secretary of Homeland Security is required to increase the number of full-time agents and support staff in the Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement by 400, and the number of full-time inspectors and support staff in the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection by 600. The Secretary is authorized to waive any limitation on the number of full-time equivalent positions. The Secretary of Homeland Security can waive limitations on personnel to fulfill requirements. Training must be provided for personnel to use new technologies and maintain proficiency levels for border protection. SEC. 9. NATIONAL BORDER SECURITY PLAN. The Secretary of Homeland Security must prepare and submit a National Border Security Plan to Congress by January 31 each year. The plan must include a vulnerability assessment of each port of entry and consultation with relevant agencies and entities involved in international trade across the northern and southern borders. The Secretary may establish port security coordinators at each port of entry on the northern or southern border to assist with vulnerability assessments and preparation of required plans.
